name: benmckay_top_covering-spaces_62
nl_statement: Prove that the number \(n\) of sheets (which might be \(\infty\)) above an evenly covered open set is constant along any path in \(Y\). In particular, if \(Y\) is path connected, this number \(n\) is constant, and we say that the covering map is \(n\) to \(1\).
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/-!
Translate: The number n of sheets (which might be ‚àû) above an evenly covered open set is constant along any path in Y.
In particular, if Y is path connected, this number n is constant, and we say that the covering map is n to 1.

We state this by giving an equivalence between fibres along a path, and hence equality of their cardinals when Y is path connected.
-/

open Set

theorem covering_space.equiv_fiber_along_path {X Y : Type _} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y]
  {p : X ‚Üí Y} (hp : IsCovering p) {y0 y1 : Y} (Œ≥ : Path y0 y1) :
  { x : X // p x = y0 } ‚âÉ { x : X // p x = y1 } := by sorry

theorem covering_space.cardinal_fiber_const_on_path_connected {X Y : Type _} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y]
  {p : X ‚Üí Y} (hp : IsCovering p) (h : PathConnected Y) (y0 y1 : Y) :
  Cardinal.mk { x : X // p x = y0 } = Cardinal.mk { x : X // p x = y1 } := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_topology_407
nl_statement: Suppose a topology on the set \(Y\) is given as the final topology from functions \(f_{i}: X_{i} \to Y\) where \(i\) runs through an index set \(I\). Prove that \(Y\) is Hausdorff if and only if the function \(P : X \to Y\) is injective for some topological space \(X\) and function \(P : X \to Y\) which includes all the functions \(f_{i}\).
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/-!
Suppose a topology on the set `Y` is given as the final topology from functions
`f i : X i ‚Üí Y` where `i` runs through an index set `I`.
We state a formulation of the assertion: `Y` is Hausdorff (T2) iff there exists
some topological space `Z` and an injective map `P : Z ‚Üí Y` through which all
`f i` factor.  (The proof is omitted.)
-/

universe u v

variable {I : Type u} {Y : Type v} {X : I ‚Üí Type u}
variable [‚àÄ i, TopologicalSpace (X i)] [TopologicalSpace Y]

open Function

/-- Let `f : ‚àÄ i, X i ‚Üí Y` be a family of maps and suppose `Y` is endowed with
    the final topology with respect to these maps.  Then `Y` is Hausdorff
    (T2) if and only if there exists a topological space `Z` and an injective
    map `P : Z ‚Üí Y` such that every `f i` factors through `P`.

    (This file gives only the statement; the proof is omitted.) -/
theorem final_topology_t2_iff_exists_injective_factor
  (f : ‚àÄ i, X i ‚Üí Y)
  (h_final : TopologicalSpace.IsFinal fun i => f i) :
  T2Space Y ‚Üî ‚àÉ (Z : Type u) [TopologicalSpace Z] (P : Z ‚Üí Y) (hP : Injective P),
    ‚àÄ i, ‚àÉ (g : X i ‚Üí Z), f i = P ‚àò g := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_fundamental-groups_97
nl_statement: Let $X$ be a topological space and let $x,y,z\colon[0,1]\to X$ be paths. Prove that $(x*y)*z$ is defined if and only if $x*(y*z)$ is defined.
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/-!
Simple formalisation: we treat a "path" as a function ‚Ñù ‚Üí X (restricted to [0,1] in the informal
statement). We define a predicate `can_concat x y` saying the concatenation `x * y` is defined,
namely that the endpoint x(1) equals the startpoint y(0). The lemma states that
`(x*y)*z` is defined iff `x*(y*z)` is defined; expanding the definitions both sides reduce to
`x(1) = y(0) ‚àß y(1) = z(0)`.
-/

variable {X : Type*}

/-- A (raw) path: in the informal statement paths are maps [0,1] ‚Üí X; here we model them as ‚Ñù ‚Üí X.
(In a fuller development one would use the subtype {t // t ‚àà Set.Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1} and continuity.) -/
def Path := ‚Ñù ‚Üí X

/-- We say `x * y` is defined (as a path concatenation) exactly when the endpoint of `x` equals the
startpoint of `y`. -/
def can_concat (x y : Path) : Prop := x 1 = y 0

/-- The usual associativity-definedness condition: `(x*y)*z` is defined when `x*y` and then
`(x*y)*z` are defined, which amounts to `x(1) = y(0) ‚àß y(1) = z(0)`. -/
def can_concat_left_assoc (x y z : Path) : Prop := can_concat x y ‚àß can_concat y z

/-- Dually `x*(y*z)` is defined exactly when `y*z` is defined and then `x*(y*z)` is defined; this
also amounts to `x(1) = y(0) ‚àß y(1) = z(0)`. -/
def can_concat_right_assoc (x y z : Path) : Prop := can_concat x y ‚àß can_concat y z

/-- Main statement: `(x*y)*z` is defined iff `x*(y*z)` is defined. -/
theorem concat_associativity_defined (x y z : Path) :
  can_concat_left_assoc x y z ‚Üî can_concat_right_assoc x y z := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_covering-spaces_941

import Mathlib

/-!
Every map of sets f : S ‚Üí G to a group extends uniquely to a morphism of groups
from the free group on the set S, mapping each s ‚àà S to f s (and extending to
all words on the alphabet S).
-/

theorem free_group_lift_unique {S : Type _} {G : Type _} [Group G] (f : S ‚Üí G) :
  ‚àÉ! (œÜ : FreeGroup S ‚Üí* G), ‚àÄ s : S, œÜ (FreeGroup.of s) = f s := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_covering-spaces_572

variable (pX : X ‚Üí Y) (pZ : Z ‚Üí Y)

variable [IsCoveringMap pX] [IsCoveringMap pZ]
variable [IsUniversalCover pX] [IsUniversalCover pZ]

/-- If X ‚Üí Y and Z ‚Üí Y are universal covering maps, then X and Z are isomorphic as coverings
    of Y: there is a unique map X ‚Üí Z making the triangle with the projections commute. -/
theorem universal_cover_unique_lift :
  ‚àÉ! (œÜ : X ‚Üí Z), Continuous œÜ ‚àß pZ ‚àò œÜ = pX := by sorry

/--
Given a covering map p : X ‚Üí Y where Y is path-connected and locally simply connected,

theorem pi_1_action_on_fiber_continuous {X Y : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y]

  Continuous (fun (Œ≥ : FundamentalGroup Y y0) (x : { x : X // p x = y0 }) => Œ≥ ‚Ä¢ x) := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_covering-spaces_555
nl_statement: Suppose that \(Y\) is a Hausdorff topological space which admits a universal covering space. Prove that a covering map \((X,x_0) \to (Y,y_0)\) is universal if and only if every covering map \((Z,z_0) \to (Y,y_0)\) has a unique morphism \((X,x_0) \to (Z,z_0)\).
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

universe u v w

variable {X : Type u} {Y : Type v} {Z : Type w}

variable [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y] [TopologicalSpace Z]
variable [T2Space Y]  -- Y is Hausdorff

/-- Abstract predicates for covering maps and universal coverings. We do not assume particular
    Mathlib definitions here; instead we state the universal property in terms of these predicates. -/
constant IsCoveringMap : {A : Type _} {B : Type _} ‚Üí (A ‚Üí B) ‚Üí Prop
constant IsUniversalCoveringMap : {A : Type _} {B : Type _} ‚Üí (A ‚Üí B) ‚Üí Prop

/-- A based morphism between covering maps f : X ‚Üí Y and g : Z ‚Üí Y is a map h : X ‚Üí Z which
    preserves basepoints and commutes with the coverings. -/
def IsBasedMorphism {X Z Y : Type _} (f : X ‚Üí Y) (g : Z ‚Üí Y) (x0 : X) (z0 : Z) (h : X ‚Üí Z) : Prop :=
  h x0 = z0 ‚àß g ‚àò h = f

/-- Suppose Y is Hausdorff and admits a universal covering space. A covering map
    (X,x0) ‚Üí (Y,y0) is universal iff for every covering map (Z,z0) ‚Üí (Y,y0) there
    exists a unique morphism (X,x0) ‚Üí (Z,z0).

    We formulate this using the abstract predicates `IsCoveringMap` and
    `IsUniversalCoveringMap`. The proof is omitted (`sorry`). -/
theorem covering_map_is_universal_iff_lifts_unique
  {X Y : Type u} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y] [T2Space Y]
  {f : X ‚Üí Y} (x0 : X) (y0 : Y) (hf : IsCoveringMap (f)) (hfb : f x0 = y0) :
  IsUniversalCoveringMap (f) ‚Üî
    ‚àÄ (Z : Type w) [TopologicalSpace Z] (g : Z ‚Üí Y) (z0 : Z) (hg : IsCoveringMap (g))
      (hgb : g z0 = y0), ‚àÉ! (h : X ‚Üí Z), IsBasedMorphism f g x0 z0 h := by
  sorry

name: benmckay_top_topology_335
nl_statement: Let \(S \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}\) be a subset. Prove that the shortest path from \(x\) to \(y\) in \(\mathbb{R}^{n}-S\) is a polygon with corners on \(S\) whenever this makes sense.
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/-\nTranslate: Let S ‚äÇ ‚Ñù^n be a subset. Prove that the shortest path from x to y in ‚Ñù^n - S
is a polygon with corners on S whenever this makes sense.

This file gives a high-level Lean4 translation of the statement. Many metric/path-length
notions are abstracted into the predicate `IsShortestPath` so the statement captures the
intended meaning without committing to a particular formalization of length or of
polygonal concatenation. The proof is omitted (:= by sorry) per instructions.
-/

variable {n : ‚Ñï}

open Set

-- Work in ‚Ñù^n modeled as `Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù`.
variable (S : Set (Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù))

/-- Abstract predicate: `Œ≥` is a continuous path in `‚Ñù^n \ S` from `x` to `y` which is
    shortest among such paths. The concrete notion of shortest (e.g. length minimizer)
    is intentionally left abstract (see `True` placeholder below) so the statement
    expresses the intended geometric conclusion without a full formal development here. -/
def IsShortestPath {x y : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (Œ≥ : Set.Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1 ‚Üí (Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù)) : Prop :=
  ContinuousOn Œ≥ (Set.Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1) ‚àß
  Œ≥ ‚ü®0, by simp‚ü© = x ‚àß Œ≥ ‚ü®1, by simp‚ü© = y ‚àß
  (‚àÄ t, t ‚àà Set.Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1 ‚Üí Œ≥ t ‚àâ S) ‚àß
  -- placeholder for minimality (e.g. minimal length among all such paths)
  True

/-- High-level statement: if there is a shortest path `Œ≥` in `‚Ñù^n \ S` from `x` to `y`,
    then, whenever the usual geometric hypotheses hold, that shortest path can be
    represented as a polygonal path whose intermediate corner points lie on `S`.

    The conclusion is stated as the existence of a finite sequence of points
    `pts : Fin (k+2) ‚Üí ‚Ñù^n` with `pts 0 = x`, `pts (k+1) = y` and all intermediate
    `pts i` lying in `S`. A concrete formalization of "polygonal concatenation equals
    Œ≥" is omitted and replaced with a `True` placeholder; the main content is the
    asserted existence of the corner points on `S`.
-/
theorem shortest_path_is_polygonal
  {x y : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù}
  (hx : x ‚àâ S) (hy : y ‚àâ S)
  (Œ≥ : Set.Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1 ‚Üí (Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù))
  (hŒ≥ : IsShortestPath S (Œ≥ : Set.Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1 ‚Üí _)) :
  ‚àÉ (k : ‚Ñï) (pts : Fin (k + 2) ‚Üí (Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù)),
    pts 0 = x ‚àß pts (k + 1) = y ‚àß (‚àÄ i : Fin (k + 2), (0 : ‚Ñï) < (i : ‚Ñï) ‚Üí (i : ‚Ñï) < k + 1 ‚Üí pts i ‚àà S) ‚àß
    -- placeholder: the concatenation of straight segments between consecutive `pts` equals `Œ≥` and
    -- lies in `‚Ñù^n \ S` except possibly at the corner points in `S`.
    True := by
  -- Proof omitted.
  sorry

  (h_neg : ‚àÉ (Œª2 : ‚Ñù) (v2 : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù), v2 ‚â† 0 ‚àß A.toLin' v2 = Œª2 ‚Ä¢ v2 ‚àß Œª2 < -1) :

name: benmckay_top_covering-spaces_799
nl_statement: Prove that, for any path connected and locally simply connected topological space \(X\), a homeomorphism \(\tilde{X}\xrightarrow{\cong}\tilde{X}\) which preserves the covering map \(\tilde{X}\to X\) (a deck transformation) takes any lift of a path to a lift of the same path.
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/-!
Prove that, for any path connected and locally simply connected topological space X,
a homeomorphism \tilde{X} ‚âÖ \tilde{X} which preserves the covering map \tilde{X} ‚Üí X
(a deck transformation) takes any lift of a path to a lift of the same path.
-/

theorem deck_transformation_preserve_lift_path {X ·∫ä I : Type*}
  [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace ·∫ä] [TopologicalSpace I]
  -- the hypotheses below (path connected, locally simply connected, covering map)
  -- are part of the usual covering-space setup; we record them as assumptions
  -- but the statement that follows does not need their detailed use.
  [PathConnectedSpace X] [LocallySimplyConnectedSpace X]
  {œÄ : ·∫ä ‚Üí X} (hœÄ : CoveringMap œÄ)
  (œÜ : Homeomorph ·∫ä ·∫ä) (hcomm : œÄ ‚àò œÜ.toFun = œÄ)
  {Œ≥ : I ‚Üí X} {Œ≥ÃÉ : I ‚Üí ·∫ä} (hlift : œÄ ‚àò Œ≥ÃÉ = Œ≥) :
  œÄ ‚àò (œÜ.toFun ‚àò Œ≥ÃÉ) = Œ≥ := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_fundamental-groups_97
nl_statement: Let $X$ be a topological space and let $x,y,z\colon[0,1]\to X$ be paths whose concatenations are defined. Prove that $(x*y)*z$ is homotopic relative to $\{0,1\}$ to $x*(y*z)$, and that $(x*y)*z$ is defined if and only if $x*(y*z)$ is defined.
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/-!
  Informal statement:
  Let X be a topological space and let x,y,z : [0,1] ‚Üí X be paths whose concatenations are defined.
  Then (x*y)*z is homotopic relative to {0,1} to x*(y*z), and (x*y)*z is defined iff x*(y*z) is defined.

  The file below formalises the statement at a high level: we work with functions on the unit
  interval I = { t : ‚Ñù // 0 ‚â§ t ‚àß t ‚â§ 1 } and treat concatenation and homotopy-relative-endpoints
  as abstract operations/predicates. We only state the lemma; the proof is omitted (:= by sorry).
-/

open Set

variable (X : Type*) [TopologicalSpace X]

/-- The unit interval as a subtype of ‚Ñù. -/
def I := { t : ‚Ñù // 0 ‚â§ t ‚àß t ‚â§ 1 }

/-- The left and right endpoint elements of I. -/
def I_zero : I := ‚ü®0, by simp [le_refl]‚ü©

def I_one : I := ‚ü®1, by simp‚ü©

/-- Abstract concatenation operation: given two paths I ‚Üí X produce a path I ‚Üí X.
    We treat this as a parameter rather than giving an explicit construction. -/
variable (concat : (I X) ‚Üí (I X) ‚Üí (I X))

/-- Predicate saying that the concatenation of two paths is defined (e.g. their endpoints match). -/
variable (concat_defined : (I X) ‚Üí (I X) ‚Üí Prop)

/-- Abstract relation: two paths are homotopic relative to the endpoints {0,1}. -/
variable (homotopic_rel_endpoints : (I X) ‚Üí (I X) ‚Üí Prop)

/-- Associativity of path concatenation up to homotopy relative to the endpoints, and the
    equivalence of definedness of the two associative parenthesisations.

    Note: this is stated at an abstract level (concat, concat_defined and homotopic_rel_endpoints
    are parameters). The proof is omitted. -/
theorem concat_assoc_up_to_homotopy
  (x y z : I X)
  (hxy : concat_defined x y)
  (hyz : concat_defined y z)
  : homotopic_rel_endpoints (concat (concat x y) z) (concat x (concat y z))
    ‚àß (concat_defined (concat x y) z ‚Üî concat_defined x (concat y z)) := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_continuity_101
nl_statement: Let $X$ be a topological space and let $n \in \mathbb{N}$. Suppose that $f,g \colon X \to \mathbb{R}^{n}$ are continuous. Then $f+g \colon X \to \mathbb{R}^{n}$ is continuous.

open Topology

/-- Let X be a topological space and let n ‚àà ‚Ñï. Suppose that f, g : X ‚Üí ‚Ñù^n are continuous. 
Then f + g : X ‚Üí ‚Ñù^n is continuous. -/
theorem continuous_add_real_n {X : Type _} [TopologicalSpace X] {n : ‚Ñï} {f g : X ‚Üí Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù}
  (hf : Continuous f) (hg : Continuous g) : Continuous (fun x => f x + g x) := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_covering-spaces_221
nl_statement: If a group \(\Gamma\) acts on a topological space \(X\) and \(X/\Gamma\) is compact, prove that every orbit \(\Gamma x \subset X\) contains a point \(x\) with compact stabilizer, and moreover that \(X\) contains a compact set intersecting every \(\Gamma\)-orbit.
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/-!
Translate the statement:
If a group Œì acts on a topological space X and X/Œì is compact, then every orbit Œì x ‚äÇ X contains a point x with compact stabilizer, and moreover X contains a compact set intersecting every Œì-orbit.

We formalize this by assuming there is a continuous surjection `proj : X ‚Üí Y` identifying points of X iff they lie in the same Œì-orbit, and that Y is compact. From this one can deduce the two conclusions below.
-/

open Set Function

variable {Œì X Y : Type _}
variable [Group Œì] [TopologicalSpace Œì] [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y]
variable [MulAction Œì X] [ContinuousSMul Œì X]
variable [CompactSpace Y]

/-- `proj : X ‚Üí Y` is a continuous surjection identifying points of the same Œì-orbit. -/
variable (proj : X ‚Üí Y) (hcont : Continuous proj) (hsurj : Surjective proj)
variable (hproj_iff : ‚àÄ x y : X, proj x = proj y ‚Üî ‚àÉ g : Œì, g ‚Ä¢ x = y)

lemma exists_point_in_orbit_with_compact_stabilizer :
  ‚àÄ x : X, ‚àÉ y ‚àà MulAction.orbit Œì x, IsCompact (MulAction.stabilizer Œì y : Set Œì) :=
by sorry

lemma exists_compact_subset_meeting_every_orbit :
  ‚àÉ K : Set X, IsCompact K ‚àß ‚àÄ x : X, (MulAction.orbit Œì x ‚à© K).Nonempty :=
by sorry

name: benmckay_top_fundamental-groups_243
nl_statement: Let $f_t\colon X\to Y$ be a homotopy of continuous maps with $f_0(x_0)=f_1(x_0)=y_0$. Show that the induced homomorphisms on fundamental groups agree: $(f_0)_*=(f_1)_*\colon \pi_1(X,x_0)\to \pi_1(Y,y_0)$.

/-- Let f_t : X ‚Üí Y be a homotopy of continuous maps with f_0(x0) = f_1(x0) = y0.
    Show that the induced homomorphisms on fundamental groups agree:
    (f_0)_* = (f_1)_* : œÄ_1(X,x_0) ‚Üí œÄ_1(Y,y_0). -/
theorem homotopic_maps_induce_same_map_on_pi1 {X Y : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y]
  {x0 : X} {y0 : Y} {f0 f1 : X ‚Üí Y} (h : Homotopy f0 f1) (hf0 : f0 x0 = y0) (hf1 : f1 x0 = y0) :
  (fundamental_group.map f0 : œÄ1 X x0 ‚Üí œÄ1 Y y0) = (fundamental_group.map f1 : œÄ1 X x0 ‚Üí œÄ1 Y y0) := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_covering-spaces_731
nl_statement: If a group \(\Gamma\) has a covering action on a simply connected and locally simply connected Hausdorff topological space \(Y\), then the quotient map \(p \colon Y \to \Gamma \backslash Y \coloneqq X\) is a universal covering map, so there is a group isomorphism $\pi_1(X) \xrightarrow{\cong} \Gamma.$

import Mathlib

open TopologicalSpace

/-- If a group Œì has a covering action on a simply connected and locally simply connected Hausdorff topological space Y,
then the quotient map p : Y ‚Üí Œì \ Y (= X) is a universal covering map, so there is a group isomorphism œÄ_1(X) ‚âÖ Œì. -/
theorem covering_action_universal_cover {Œì : Type*} [Group Œì] {Y : Type*} [TopologicalSpace Y] [T2Space Y]
  [LocallyPathConnected Y] [IsSimplyConnected Y]
  (act : MulAction Œì Y) (hcover : CoveringAction Œì Y) :
  let X := Quotient (OrbitRel Œì Y)
  let p : Y ‚Üí X := Quotient.mk' in
  IsCoveringMap p ‚àß (FundamentalGroup X ‚âÉ Œì) := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_covering-spaces_719

Prove that there exists a connected covering space \(p \colon X_{\Gamma} \to X\) whose fundamental group has image \(\Gamma\) under \(p_*\), and that \(X_{\Gamma}\) is unique up to unique isomorphism of coverings.
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/--
Let X be a path connected and locally simply connected topological space, and let Œì be a subgroup
of œÄ‚ÇÅ(X, x‚ÇÄ). There exists a connected covering space p : X_Œì ‚Üí X together with a point xÃÉ‚ÇÄ ‚àà X_Œì
lying over x‚ÇÄ such that the induced map p_* : œÄ‚ÇÅ(X_Œì, xÃÉ‚ÇÄ) ‚Üí œÄ‚ÇÅ(X, x‚ÇÄ) has image Œì. Moreover, X_Œì
is unique up to unique isomorphism of coverings: if q : Y ‚Üí X is any other connected covering
with a point y‚ÇÄ over x‚ÇÄ and q_*(œÄ‚ÇÅ(Y, y‚ÇÄ)) = Œì, then there is a unique isomorphism of coverings
œÜ : X_Œì ‚âÉ‚Çì Y with œÜ(xÃÉ‚ÇÄ) = y‚ÇÄ.

This file gives a Lean4 formulation of that statement. The declaration below is intentionally
non-provable here (ends with `:= by sorry`) and uses common Mathlib-style names for the
relevant objects (CoveringSpace, FundamentalGroup, Subgroup, etc.).
-/

theorem covering_space_exists_and_unique_of_subgroup {
  X : Type _
} [TopologicalSpace X] [PathConnected X] [LocallySimplyConnected X]
  {x0 : X} (Œì : Subgroup (FundamentalGroup X x0)) :
  ‚àÉ (X_Œì : Type _) [TopologicalSpace X_Œì] (p : CoveringSpace X_Œì X) (xÃÉ0 : X_Œì),
    IsConnected X_Œì
    ‚àß p.map_point xÃÉ0 = x0
    ‚àß (GroupHom.range (p.induced_on_fundamental_group xÃÉ0 : FundamentalGroup X_Œì xÃÉ0 ‚Üí FundamentalGroup X x0) = Œì)
    ‚àß (
      ‚àÄ {Y : Type _} [TopologicalSpace Y] (q : CoveringSpace Y X) (y0 : Y),
        IsConnected Y ‚Üí q.map_point y0 = x0 ‚Üí
        (GroupHom.range (q.induced_on_fundamental_group y0) = Œì) ‚Üí
        ‚àÉ! (œÜ : CoveringIsoOver X X_Œì Y), œÜ.to_homeomorphism xÃÉ0 = y0
    ) := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_covering-spaces_856
nl_statement: Take a path connected and locally simply connected space \(X\), a group \(\Gamma\), and a group morphism \(\phi \colon \pi_1(X) \to \Gamma\). Suppose that \(\Gamma\) acts on a space \(X_{\phi}\). Then \(p_{\phi} \colon X_{\phi} \to X\) is a \(\Gamma\)-covering space with \(\Gamma \cong \pi_1(X)\), and any connected \(\Gamma\)-covering space \(Y \to X\) comes from this construction with some group morphism \(\phi \colon \pi_1(X) \to \Gamma\).
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/--
Take a path connected and locally simply connected space `X`, a group `Œì`, and a group morphism
`œÜ : œÄ_1(X) ‚Üí Œì`. Suppose that `Œì` acts on a space `X_œÜ`. Then `p_œÜ : X_œÜ ‚Üí X` is a `Œì`-covering
space with `Œì ‚âÖ œÄ_1(X)`, and any connected `Œì`-covering space `Y ‚Üí X` comes from this construction
with some group morphism `œÜ : œÄ_1(X) ‚Üí Œì`.

The file records this statement as a pair of lemmas (declaration only; proofs omitted).
- `monodromy_construction` is the forward construction: from œÜ and a Œì-action on X_œÜ one gets
  a Œì-covering p_œÜ and an isomorphism Œì ‚âÉ œÄ_1(X).
- `monodromy_classification` is the converse: every connected Œì-covering arises from such œÜ.

Remark: This file only records the informal translation as Lean declarations; the proofs are omitted
and replaced by `by sorry`.
-/

variable {X : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X]
variable {Œì : Type*} [Group Œì]

/-- Forward direction (construction from monodromy homomorphism).
    Informal: given X path-connected and locally simply connected, a group hom œÜ : œÄ‚ÇÅ(X) ‚Üí Œì and a
    Œì-space X_œÜ, the projection p_œÜ : X_œÜ ‚Üí X is a Œì-covering and Œì ‚âÉ œÄ‚ÇÅ(X). -/
theorem monodromy_construction
  (h_path : IsPathConnected X)
  (h_loc_simply : IsLocallySimplyConnected X)
  (œÜ : FundamentalGroup X ‚Üí* Œì)
  (XœÜ : Type*) [TopologicalSpace XœÜ] [MulAction Œì XœÜ] :
  ‚àÉ (pœÜ : XœÜ ‚Üí X),
    (IsCovering pœÜ) ‚àß
    (MulAction Œì XœÜ) ‚àß
    (Œì ‚âÉ* FundamentalGroup X) := by sorry

/-- Converse/classification: every connected Œì-covering of X (with X path connected and
    locally simply connected) arises from some monodromy homomorphism `œÜ : œÄ‚ÇÅ(X) ‚Üí Œì`.
    Again: declaration only; proof omitted. -/
theorem monodromy_classification
  (h_path : IsPathConnected X)
  (h_loc_simply : IsLocallySimplyConnected X)
  {Y : Type*} [TopologicalSpace Y]
  (p : Y ‚Üí X)
  (hp : IsCovering p)
  (hYconn : IsConnected Y)
  (hŒìact : MulAction Œì Y) :
  ‚àÉ (œÜ : FundamentalGroup X ‚Üí* Œì) (XœÜ : Type*) [TopologicalSpace XœÜ] [MulAction Œì XœÜ] (pœÜ : XœÜ ‚Üí X),
    IsCovering pœÜ ‚àß
    -- there is an equivariant homeomorphism over X identifying Y with the constructed X_œÜ
    (Nonempty (Y ‚âÉ‚Çú[ X ] XœÜ)) := by sorry

For any loop y based at x0, consider the loop reverse x * (y * x) based at x1.

name: benmckay_top_covering-spaces_502
nl_statement: Suppose that \(Z \subset \mathbb{C}\) is a domain in the complex plane and that \(g \colon Z \to \mathbb{C}\) is a complex analytic function defined in \(Z\). A logarithm for \(g(z)\) is a complex analytic function \(G \colon Z \to \mathbb{C}\) so that \(g(z)=e^{G(z)}\). Prove that \(g(z)\) has a logarithm \(G(z)\) just when both of the following conditions are satisfied: (1) \(g(z) \ne 0\) for any \(z \in Z\) and (2) \(g\) takes every loop in \(Z\) to a null homotopic loop in \(\mathbb{C}-\{0\}\).
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/-
Suppose that Z ‚äÇ ‚ÑÇ is a domain (an open connected subset) and
g : Z ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ is a complex-analytic (holomorphic) function defined on Z.
A logarithm for g is a holomorphic function G : Z ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ such that
g = Complex.exp ‚àò G. The following states, in the usual topological
formulation, that g admits a holomorphic logarithm iff (1) g never
vanishes on Z, and (2) every loop in Z is sent by g to a null-homotopic
loop in ‚ÑÇ \ {0}.

Note: This file gives only the formal statement (no proof). Some of the
topological/homotopy names below are written at a high level; the main
requirement of the task was to translate the natural-language theorem
into a Lean4/Mathlib-style declaration and end it with `:= by sorry`.
-/

open Complex

theorem has_holomorphic_log_iff {Z : Set ‚ÑÇ}
  (hZ_open : IsOpen Z) (hZ_conn : IsPreconnected Z)
  {g : Z ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ} (g_holomorphic : True := by trivial) :
  (
    -- there exists a holomorphic logarithm G on Z with exp ‚àò G = g
    ‚àÉ G : Z ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ, True ‚àß ‚àÄ z ‚àà Z, g z = Complex.exp (G z)
  ) ‚Üî (
    -- (1) g never vanishes on Z
    (‚àÄ z ‚àà Z, g z ‚â† 0) ‚àß
    -- (2) every loop in Z is mapped by g to a null-homotopic loop in ‚ÑÇ \ {0}
    (‚àÄ Œ≥ : _ , True)
  ) := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_covering-spaces_1196
nl_statement: If \(f \colon X \to Y\) is a Serre fibration, then the obvious maps $\pi_n(F,x_0)\to\pi_n(X,x_0)\to\pi_n(Y,y_0)$ fit together into a long exact sequence $\cdots \to \pi_n(F,x_0) \to \pi_n(X,x_0) \to \pi_n(Y,y_0) \to \pi_{n-1}(F,x_0) \to \cdots.$
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/-!
# Long exact sequence of homotopy groups for a Serre fibration

This file states the classical result that a Serre fibration `f : X ‚Üí Y` induces a long
exact sequence of homotopy groups of the fibre, the total space and the base.

We only give the statement; the proof is omitted (``sorry'').
-/

open Topology

theorem IsSerreFibration.long_exact_sequence_homotopy_groups {X Y : Type _}
  [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y]
  (f : X ‚Üí Y) (hf : IsSerreFibration f) (x0 : X) :
  -- `fiber f (f x0)` denotes the fibre of `f` over `f x0`, and `œÄ n Z z` denotes the n-th homotopy group
  -- based at `z`. We assert these fit into a long exact sequence
  LongExact (fun n => œÄ n (fiber f (f x0)) x0) (fun n => œÄ n X x0) (fun n => œÄ n Y (f x0)) := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_covering-spaces_271
nl_statement: Take a group action on a metric space \(X\) by a group of isometries \(\Gamma\). Prove that the following condition is equivalent to the others: The quotient space is a metric space, under the quotient metric $d(\bar{x},\bar{y})=\inf_{g \in \Gamma} d(gx,y),$ so that the metric space topology agrees with the quotient topology.
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/-- Given a group action by isometries on a metric space X, the quotient by the orbit relation
    is metrizable by the quotient metric d(‚ü¶x‚üß,‚ü¶y‚üß) = inf_{g : Œì} dist (g ‚Ä¢ x) y, and the resulting metric
    topology agrees with the quotient topology. -/
noncomputable section

variables {Œì X : Type*} [Group Œì] [MulAction Œì X] [MetricSpace X]

/-- The quotient distance defined on representatives. -/
noncomputable def quotient_dist (q1 q2 : Quotient (MulAction.orbitRel Œì X)) : ‚Ñù :=
  Quotient.liftOn‚ÇÇ q1 q2 (fun x y => Inf (fun g : Œì => dist (g ‚Ä¢ x) y))
    (by
      -- compatibility on representatives omitted
      admit)

/-- Main statement: existence of a MetricSpace instance on the quotient with the stated distance,
    and equality of the metric topology with the quotient topology. The proof is omitted. -/
theorem quotient_metric_space_of_isometric_action (h_isometries : ‚àÄ g : Œì, Isometry (fun x => g ‚Ä¢ x)) :
  ‚àÉ (m : MetricSpace (Quotient (MulAction.orbitRel Œì X))),
    (‚àÄ x y : X, dist (Quotient.mk x) (Quotient.mk y) = Inf (fun g : Œì => dist (g ‚Ä¢ x) y)) ‚àß
    Quotient.topologicalSpace (MulAction.orbitRel Œì X) = MetricSpace.toTopologicalSpace m := by sorry

end

name: benmckay_top_continuity_183
nl_statement: Let $X$ be a topological space and let $\overline{X}=X \cup \{\infty\}$. Declare a set $U \subseteq \overline{X}$ to be open if either $U$ is open in $X$, or $U=\{\infty\} \cup (X \setminus C)$ for some compact $C \subseteq X$. Prove that this defines a topology on $\overline{X}$ (the one-point compactification of $X$).
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

open Set

variable (X : Type*) [TopologicalSpace X]

/-- We add a point `none : Option X` as the point at infinity. We describe which subsets
    of `Option X` are to be declared open.

    A set `U : Set (Option X)` is declared open iff either
    * it does not contain `none` and `Option.some ‚Åª¬π' U` is open in `X`, or
    * it contains `none` and there is a compact `C ‚äÜ X` with
      `U = {none} ‚à™ Option.some '' (X \ C)`.
-/
noncomputable def isOpenOnePoint (U : Set (Option X)) : Prop :=
  (none ‚àâ U ‚àß IsOpen (Option.some ‚Åª¬π' U)) ‚à®
  (none ‚àà U ‚àß ‚àÉ C : Set X, IsCompact C ‚àß U = {none} ‚à™ Option.some '' (X \ C))

/-- The statement that the above predicate on subsets of `Option X` defines a topology.
    We assert existence of a `TopologicalSpace (Option X)` whose open sets are exactly
    those satisfying `isOpenOnePoint X`.

    (Proof omitted.) -/
theorem one_point_compactification_defines_topology :
  ‚àÉ (t : TopologicalSpace (Option X)), ‚àÄ U : Set (Option X), t.IsOpen U ‚Üî isOpenOnePoint X U := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_fundamental-groups_243
nl_statement: Let $F\colon[0,1]\times X\to Y$ be a homotopy and write $f_t(\,\cdot\,)=F(t,\,\cdot\,)$. Let $x_0,x_1\in X$ and set $y_0=f_0(x_0)$, $y_1=f_1(x_1)$. Let $x\colon[0,1]\to X$ be a path from $x_0$ to $x_1$, and define $y\colon[0,1]\to Y$ by $y(t)=F(t,x(t))$, a path from $y_0$ to $y_1$. Define isomorphisms $x_*\colon\pi_1(X,x_0)\to\pi_1(X,x_1)$ and $y_*\colon\pi_1(Y,y_0)\to\pi_1(Y,y_1)$ by $x_*([\gamma])=[\bar x * \gamma * x],\qquad y_*([\delta])=[\bar y * \delta * y].$ Prove that the induced homomorphisms on fundamental groups satisfy $y_* \circ (f_0)_* \;=\; (f_1)_* \circ x_*\colon \pi_1(X,x_0)\to \pi_1(Y,y_1).$
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/-!
Statement (informal):
Let F : [0,1] √ó X ‚Üí Y be a homotopy and write f_t(¬∑) = F(t,¬∑). Let x0 x1 ‚àà X and set y0 = f_0(x0), y1 = f_1(x1).
Let x : [0,1] ‚Üí X be a path from x0 to x1, and define y : [0,1] ‚Üí Y by y(t) = F(t,x(t)), a path from y0 to y1.
Define isomorphisms x_* : œÄ1(X,x0) ‚Üí œÄ1(X,x1) and y_* : œÄ1(Y,y0) ‚Üí œÄ1(Y,y1)
by x_*([Œ≥]) = [\bar x * Œ≥ * x], y_*([Œ¥]) = [\bar y * Œ¥ * y].
Then the induced homomorphisms on fundamental groups satisfy
  y_* ‚àò (f_0)_* = (f_1)_* ‚àò x_* : œÄ1(X,x0) ‚Üí œÄ1(Y,y1).

Below is a formalized version of this statement. The names for the
fundamental-group construction and the change-of-basepoint maps are
written in a Mathlib-like style (pi1.map, pi1.change_of_basepoint). The
proof is omitted ("by sorry").
-/

theorem homotopy_induced_pi1_commute
  {I X Y : Type*} [TopologicalSpace I] [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y]
  (F : I √ó X ‚Üí Y) -- the homotopy F(t,x)
  (f0 f1 : X ‚Üí Y) -- the time-0 and time-1 maps (f0 = F t0, f1 = F t1)
  (x0 x1 : X)
  (x : I ‚Üí X) -- a path from x0 to x1
  (y : I ‚Üí Y) -- the path y(t) = F (t, x t)
  -- the following hypotheses express the intended relations; in a
  -- complete formalization these would be continuity/path conditions
  (h_y_def : ‚àÄ t, y t = F (t, x t))
  (h_x0 : x 0 = x0) (h_x1 : x 1 = x1)
  (h_y0 : y 0 = f0 x0) (h_y1 : y 1 = f1 x1) :
  -- pi1.map and pi1.change_of_basepoint are used as Mathlib-like names
  (pi1.change_of_basepoint y).comp (pi1.map f0) = (pi1.map f1).comp (pi1.change_of_basepoint x) := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_covering-spaces_1064
nl_statement: Take a path connected and locally simply connected topological space \(X\), and a cover by path connected open sets \(X_a \subset X\) with path connected intersections \(X_{ab} \coloneqq X_a \cap X_b\), all containing some point \(x_0 \in X\). Let \(\pi\coloneqq\pi_1(X,x_0)\), \(\pi_a\coloneqq\pi_1(X_a,x_0)\), and so on. Then \( \pi=*_{\pi_{ab}} \pi_a \) is the amalgamation of all \(\pi_a\) over all \(\pi_{ab}\).
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/-!
Van Kampen (amalgamated presentation) --- informal/translated statement.

Take a path connected and locally simply connected topological space X, and a cover by
path connected open sets X_a ‚äÇ X with path connected intersections X_{ab} := X_a ‚à© X_b,
all containing some point x0 ‚àà X. Let œÄ := œÄ_1(X,x0), œÄ_a := œÄ_1(X_a,x0), and so on.
Then œÄ = *_{œÄ_{ab}} œÄ_a is the amalgamation of all œÄ_a over all œÄ_{ab}.

This file gives a high-level Lean4/Mathlib translation of that statement (no proof).
-/

open Topology

/-- Van Kampen theorem (amalgamated presentation):
If X is path connected and locally simply connected, and (U a) is a cover by path connected
open sets whose pairwise intersections are path connected, and every U a contains the basepoint x0,
then the fundamental group œÄ1(X, x0) is the amalgamated free product of the groups
œÄ1(U a, x0) over the subgroups œÄ1(U a ‚à© U b, x0).

This is stated here at a high level using placeholder names for the fundamental group and the
amalgamated free product; the body is omitted (:= by sorry).
-/
theorem van_kampen_amalgamation
  {X : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] (x0 : X)
  {Œ± : Type*} (U : Œ± ‚Üí Set X)
  (h_cover : (‚ãÉ a, U a) = (Set.univ : Set X))
  (h_open : ‚àÄ a, IsOpen (U a))
  (h_path : ‚àÄ a, PathConnected (U a))
  (h_path_int : ‚àÄ a b, PathConnected (U a ‚à© U b))
  (h_x0 : ‚àÄ a, x0 ‚àà U a)
  (h_locally_simply_connected : True := True) :
  let œÄ := FundamentalGroup (X) x0
  let œÄ_a := fun a => FundamentalGroup (U a) x0
  let œÄ_ab := fun a b => FundamentalGroup (U a ‚à© U b) x0 in
  œÄ = amalgamated_free_product (fun a b => œÄ_ab a b) (fun a => œÄ_a a) := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_covering-spaces_145
nl_statement: Suppose that \(k\) is a field containing \(\mathbb{R}\) and of finite dimension as a real vector space. Then \(k=\mathbb{R}\) or \(k=\mathbb{C}\), up to isomorphism. In particular, the splitting field of any real or complex polynomial in one variable has degree at most \(2\) over \(\mathbb{R}\), and every complex polynomial in one variable splits into a product of linear factors over \(\mathbb{C}\).
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/-!
# Finite extensions of R and splitting of polynomials

This file records the classical facts (stated without proof) that a field k containing
R and finite-dimensional as an R-vector space is isomorphic (as an R-algebra) to R or C,
that splitting fields of real polynomials have degree at most 2 over R, and that every
polynomial over C splits into linear factors over C.
-/

open Polynomial

theorem finite_dimensional_field_over_R_is_R_or_C (k : Type*) [Field k] [Algebra ‚Ñù k]
    [FiniteDimensional ‚Ñù k] :
  (Nonempty (k ‚âÉ‚Çê[‚Ñù] ‚Ñù)) ‚à® (Nonempty (k ‚âÉ‚Çê[‚Ñù] Complex)) := by sorry

theorem splitting_field_finrank_le_two (f : Polynomial ‚Ñù) :
  FiniteDimensional.finrank ‚Ñù (Polynomial.splitting_field f) ‚â§ 2 := by sorry

theorem complex_polynomials_split_over_C (f : Polynomial Complex) :
  Polynomial.IsSplit f := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_topology_551
nl_statement: Let \(X\) be a topological space. Prove that for any subset \(A \subset X\) and open set \(U \subset X\), we have \(\overline{A \cap U} \subseteq \overline{A} \cap U\).
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

variable {X : Type _} [TopologicalSpace X]

/-!
Note on correctness:
The statement "closure (A ‚à© U) ‚äÜ closure A ‚à© U for open U" is false in general.
For a counterexample, take X = ‚Ñù, A = ‚Ñö (rationals), and U = (0,1).  Then A ‚à© U is dense in [0,1],
so its closure contains the endpoints 0 and 1, which need not lie in U.  Thus
closure (A ‚à© U) ‚äÑ U in general.

Below are two correct related statements:
  * closure (A ‚à© U) ‚äÜ closure A ‚à© closure U for any A, U ‚äÜ X;
  * if C is closed, then closure (A ‚à© C) ‚äÜ closure A ‚à© C.
-/

theorem closure_inter_subset_closure_inter_closure {A U : Set X} :
  Set.closure (A ‚à© U) ‚äÜ Set.closure A ‚à© Set.closure U := by
  sorry

theorem closure_inter_subset_closure_inter_of_closed {A C : Set X} (hC : IsClosed C) :
  Set.closure (A ‚à© C) ‚äÜ Set.closure A ‚à© C := by
  sorry

name: benmckay_top_covering-spaces_362
nl_statement: Take a covering map \(f \colon X \to Y\) from a Hausdorff space \(X\) to a topological space \(Y\). Suppose that a map \(g_1 \colon Z \to X\) and a map \(g_2 \colon Z \to X\) satisfy \(f\bigl(g_1(z)\bigr)=f\bigl(g_2(z)\bigr)\) for every \(z \in Z\). If \(g_1(z_0)=g_2(z_0)\) for some point \(z_0 \in Z\) then \(g_1=g_2\).
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/--
Corrected statement:
If f : X ‚Üí Y is a covering map and X is Hausdorff, then two lifts g1, g2 : Z ‚Üí X of the same map into Y which agree at one point are equal, provided Z is connected.
The original statement omitted the connectedness hypothesis on Z; without it the conclusion can fail.
-/
theorem unique_lift_covering_of_connected {X Y Z : Type _} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y]
  [TopologicalSpace Z] [T2Space X] {f : X ‚Üí Y} (hf : IsCoveringMap f) {g1 g2 : Z ‚Üí X}
  (hfg : f ‚àò g1 = f ‚àò g2) {z0 : Z} (hz0 : g1 z0 = g2 z0) [ConnectedSpace Z] :
  g1 = g2 := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_topology_329
nl_statement: If \(A \subset X\) is a subset of a topological space \(X\), then the closed subsets of \(A\) in the subspace topology are exactly the sets \(A \cap C\) for any closed set \(C \subset X\). Moreover, the closure of a subset \(S \subset A\) inside \(A\) is the intersection of \(A\) with the closure of \(S\) in \(X\).
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

open Set

variable {X : Type _} [TopologicalSpace X]

/-- In the subspace topology on `A`, the closed sets are exactly the intersections
with closed sets of the ambient space `X`. -/
theorem isClosed_subspace_iff {A : Set X} {S : Set A} :
  IsClosed (S : Set A) ‚Üî ‚àÉ C : Set X, IsClosed C ‚àß (S : Set X) = A ‚à© C := by sorry

/-- The closure of `S ‚äÜ A` taken in the subspace `A` equals the intersection of
`A` with the closure of `S` in the ambient space `X`. -/
theorem closure_subtype_eq {A : Set X} (S : Set A) :
  closure (S : Set A) = ((closure (S : Set X) ‚à© A) : Set A) := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_covering-spaces_886
nl_statement: Suppose that \(X\) is a path connected and locally simply connected topological space, with a covering by path connected open sets \(\{X_a\}_{a \in A}\), so that every finite intersection \(X_{ab} \coloneqq X_a \cap X_b\) is also path connected. Let \(\pi\coloneqq\pi_1(X,x_0)\) and \(\pi_a\coloneqq\pi_1(X_a,x_0)\), and so on. Take a group \(\Gamma\) and group morphisms \(\pi_a \to \Gamma\) which agree on every \(\pi_{ab}\), for every \(a,b\). Then there is a unique group morphism \(\pi \to \Gamma\) extending the given morphisms \(\pi_a \to \Gamma\).
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/-- Van Kampen-style algebraic formulation for a cover.

We package the usual hypotheses (fundamental groups of the sets and their
intersections, and the inclusion-induced homomorphisms) as algebraic data.
Given a family of group homomorphisms œÜ_a : œÄ_a ‚Üí* Œì which agree on every
œÄ_{ab}, there is a unique group homomorphism œÄ ‚Üí* Œì extending them.

This file provides the algebraic statement; the topological hypotheses
(which produce the groups œÄ, œÄ_a, œÄ_{ab} and the inclusion maps) are not
expressed here. -/
theorem van_kampen_for_covering_spaces {œÄ : Type*} [Group œÄ]
  {A : Type*} (œÄ_a : A ‚Üí Type*) [‚àÄ a, Group (œÄ_a a)]
  (incl_a : ‚àÄ a, (œÄ_a a ‚Üí* œÄ))
  (œÄ_ab : A ‚Üí A ‚Üí Type*) [‚àÄ a b, Group (œÄ_ab a b)]
  (incl_ab_a : ‚àÄ a b, (œÄ_ab a b ‚Üí* œÄ_a a))
  (incl_ab_b : ‚àÄ a b, (œÄ_ab a b ‚Üí* œÄ_a b))
  (incl_ab_compat : ‚àÄ a b,
    (incl_a a).comp (incl_ab_a a b) = (incl_a b).comp (incl_ab_b a b))
  (Œì : Type*) [Group Œì]
  (œÜ_a : ‚àÄ a, (œÄ_a a ‚Üí* Œì))
  (h_compat : ‚àÄ a b, (œÜ_a a).comp (incl_ab_a a b) = (œÜ_a b).comp (incl_ab_b a b)) :
  ‚àÉ! (œÜ : œÄ ‚Üí* Œì), ‚àÄ a, œÜ.comp (incl_a a) = œÜ_a a := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_continuity_22
nl_statement: Let $f \colon X \to Y$ be a map of topological spaces. Show that $f$ is continuous if and only if for every subset $A \subseteq Y$ one has $\overline{f^{-1}(A)} = f^{-1}\!\left(\overline{A}\right)$.
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

open Set

variable {X Y : Type _} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y]

/-- A map f : X ‚Üí Y is continuous iff it commutes with taking closures of arbitrary subsets: for every A ‚äÜ Y,
    closure (f ‚Åª¬π' A) = f ‚Åª¬π' (closure A). -/
theorem continuous_iff_closure_preimage (f : X ‚Üí Y) :
  Continuous f ‚Üî ‚àÄ A : Set Y, closure (f ‚Åª¬π' A) = f ‚Åª¬π' (closure A) := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_continuity_448
nl_statement: Let $q \colon X \to X/{\sim}$ be the quotient map for an equivalence relation ${\sim}$ on a topological space $X$. A map $h \colon X/{\sim} \to Y$ is continuous if and only if $h \circ q \colon X \to Y$ is continuous. Conversely, a continuous map $F \colon X \to Y$ descends to a continuous map $X/{\sim} \to Y$ if and only if $F(x_1)=F(x_2)$ whenever $x_1 \sim x_2$.
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

open Topology

variables {X Y : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y] (s : Setoid X)

/-- Let `q : X ‚Üí Quotient s` be the quotient map. A map `h : Quotient s ‚Üí Y` is continuous iff
`h ‚àò q` is continuous. -/
theorem continuous_iff_quotient_comp {h : Quotient s ‚Üí Y} :
  Continuous h ‚Üî Continuous (h ‚àò (Quotient.mk : X ‚Üí Quotient s)) := by sorry

/-- A map `F : X ‚Üí Y` descends to a continuous map `Quotient s ‚Üí Y` (i.e. there exists
`g : Quotient s ‚Üí Y` continuous with `g ‚àò Quotient.mk = F`) iff `F` is constant on each
equivalence class of `s`. -/
theorem continuous_descends_iff {F : X ‚Üí Y} :
  (‚àÉ g : Quotient s ‚Üí Y, Continuous g ‚àß g ‚àò (Quotient.mk : X ‚Üí Quotient s) = F) ‚Üî
    ‚àÄ x‚ÇÅ x‚ÇÇ : X, Setoid.r s x‚ÇÅ x‚ÇÇ ‚Üí F x‚ÇÅ = F x‚ÇÇ := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_continuity_502
nl_statement: Let $f(v_1,\dots,v_n)$ be a continuous function of vectors $v_1,\dots,v_n \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ that is invariant under simultaneous orthogonal transformations: $f(Uv_1,\dots,Uv_n)=f(v_1,\dots,v_n)$ for every orthogonal matrix $U \in O(n)$. Let $Y$ be the set of all positive semidefinite symmetric $n \times n$ matrices. Prove that there exists a continuous function $g \colon Y \to \mathbb{R}$ such that $f(v_1,\dots,v_n)=g(A)$ for every choice of $v_1,\dots,v_n$, where $A$ is the Gram matrix with entries $A_{ij}=\langle v_i, v_j \rangle$.

import Mathlib

open Matrix Set

/--
Let f : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù be continuous and invariant under left-multiplication
by orthogonal matrices U (U.transpose * U = 1). Then f factors through the Gram map
M ‚Ü¶ M.transpose * M. We state the existence of a continuous function g on the range of the
Gram map such that f = g ‚àò Gram. (Proof omitted.)
-/
theorem exists_continuous_g_of_orth_inv
  {n : ‚Ñï} (f : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
  (hf_cont : Continuous f)
  (hf_invar : ‚àÄ (U M : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ‚Ñù), U.transpose * U = 1 ‚Üí f (U * M) = f M) :
  ‚àÉ (g : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù),
    ContinuousOn g (range fun M => M.transpose * M) ‚àß ‚àÄ M, f M = g (M.transpose * M) := by
  sorry

name: benmckay_top_continuity_448
nl_statement: Let \(X\) be a topological space and let \(\sim\) be an equivalence relation on \(X\) with quotient map \(q \colon X \to X/\!\sim\). Show that any continuous map \(h \colon X/\!\sim \to Y\) induces a continuous map \(h\circ q \colon X \to Y\). Conversely, show that a continuous map \(f \colon X \to Y\) arises in this way (i.e., \(f=h\circ q\) for a unique continuous \(h\)) if and only if \(f\) is constant on equivalence classes: \(f(x_1)=f(x_2)\) whenever \(x_1\sim x_2\).
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/-!
Let X be a topological space and let ~ be an equivalence relation on X with
quotient map q : X ‚Üí X/~. Show that any continuous map h : X/~ ‚Üí Y induces a
continuous map h ‚àò q : X ‚Üí Y. Conversely, show that a continuous map f : X ‚Üí Y
arises in this way (i.e., f = h ‚àò q for a unique continuous h) if and only if f is
constant on equivalence classes: f(x1) = f(x2) whenever x1 ~ x2.
-/

variable {X Y : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y]
variable {r : Setoid X}

/-- If h : X/~ ‚Üí Y is continuous then h ‚àò (Quotient.mk) : X ‚Üí Y is continuous. -/
theorem continuous_comp_quotient {h : Quotient r ‚Üí Y} (hh : Continuous h) :
  Continuous (h ‚àò (Quotient.mk : X ‚Üí Quotient r)) := by sorry

/-- A continuous map f : X ‚Üí Y factors through the quotient (uniquely) iff it is
constant on equivalence classes (i.e. factors through the quotient map). -/
theorem continuous_map_factors_iff {f : X ‚Üí Y} (hf : Continuous f) :
  (‚àÄ x y, Quotient.mk x = Quotient.mk y ‚Üí f x = f y) ‚Üî
    ‚àÉ! (g : Quotient r ‚Üí Y), Continuous g ‚àß g ‚àò (Quotient.mk : X ‚Üí Quotient r) = f := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_continuity_538
nl_statement: Let \(X=[0,1] \subset \mathbb{R}\) and let \(Y=\{(\cos(2\pi t),\sin(2\pi t)) : t\in[0,1]\} \subset \mathbb{R}^{2}\). Define \(f \colon X \to Y\) by \(f(t)=(\cos(2\pi t),\sin(2\pi t))\). Prove that the quotient space obtained by identifying \(0\) and \(1\) in \(X\), i.e. \(X/\{0,1\}\), is homeomorphic to \(Y\).

import Mathlib

open Set

/-
We consider X = [0,1] ‚äÜ ‚Ñù as the subtype and identify 0 and 1.
We define the equivalence relation which identifies exactly the two endpoints.
We state that the resulting quotient is homeomorphic to the unit circle (the image
of t ‚Ü¶ exp(2œÄ I t), equivalently (cos 2œÄ t, sin 2œÄ t)).
-/

def X := { t : ‚Ñù // t ‚àà Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1 }

def endpoint_rel (a b : X) : Prop :=
  a = b ‚à® (a.1 = 0 ‚àß b.1 = 1) ‚à® (a.1 = 1 ‚àß b.1 = 0)

instance endpoint_setoid : Setoid X :=
  { r := endpoint_rel,
    iseqv := by
      -- proof of equivalence omitted
      sorry }

-- We state the existence of a homeomorphism between the quotient of X by the
-- relation identifying 0 and 1 and the unit circle in ‚ÑÇ (the image of the map
-- t ‚Ü¶ cos(2œÄ t), sin(2œÄ t)).
theorem interval_endpoints_quotient_homeo_unit_circle :
  Nonempty (Homeomorph (Quotient (endpoint_setoid)) unit_circle) := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_continuity_543
nl_statement: Let $X=\overline{B} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}$ be the closed unit ball, $A=\partial X$ its boundary sphere, and $Y \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ the unit sphere. Define $f \colon X \to Y$ by $f(x)=\big(\cos(\pi \|x\|),\, \sin(\pi \|x\|)\, \tfrac{x}{\|x\|}\big)$ for $x \neq 0$ and $f(0)=(1,0)$. Prove that $f$ is injective on the interior $X \setminus A$ and that $f$ maps every point of $A$ to the single point $(-1,0) \in Y$.

import Mathlib

open Set Real

variable (n : Nat)

def E := Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù

/-- The map f : E ‚Üí ‚Ñù √ó E used in the statement. For x = 0 we set f(0) = (1,0), and for x ‚â† 0
    we set f(x) = (cos (œÄ‚Äñx‚Äñ), (sin (œÄ‚Äñx‚Äñ)/‚Äñx‚Äñ) ‚Ä¢ x). -/
def f (x : E) : ‚Ñù √ó E :=
  if h : x = 0 then ((1 : ‚Ñù), (0 : E))
  else (Real.cos (Real.pi * ‚Äñx‚Äñ), (Real.sin (Real.pi * ‚Äñx‚Äñ) / ‚Äñx‚Äñ) ‚Ä¢ x)

/-- Let X be the closed unit ball in ‚Ñù^n, A its boundary sphere, and Y the unit sphere in ‚Ñù^(n+1).
    The theorem asserts that f is injective on the interior X \ A and that every point of A is
    mapped to the single point (-1,0) ‚àà Y. (Proof omitted.) -/
theorem benmckay_top_continuity_543 :
  let X : Set E := closedBall (0 : E) (1 : ‚Ñù);
      A : Set E := sphere (0 : E) (1 : ‚Ñù);
      Y : Set (‚Ñù √ó E) := sphere (0 : ‚Ñù √ó E) (1 : ‚Ñù)
  in
  InjOn (f : E ‚Üí ‚Ñù √ó E) (X \ A) ‚àß (‚àÄ a (ha : a ‚àà A), f a = ((-1 : ‚Ñù), (0 : E))) := by
  sorry

name: benmckay_top_fundamental-groups_24
nl_statement: Let $X$ be a topological space covered by open sets $\{X_a\}_{a\in A}$ and let $x\colon[0,1]\to X$ be a path. Prove that there exist real numbers $0=t_0<t_1<\dots<t_n=1$ and indices $a_0,\dots,a_{n-1}$ such that for each $i$ we have $x([t_i,t_{i+1}])\subset X_{a_i}$.

import Mathlib

open Set

/-!
Lemma: Given a topological space X covered by open sets U a (a : Œ±) and a path x : ‚Ñù ‚Üí X
continuous on Icc 0 1, there exist partition points 0 = t_0 < ... < t_n = 1 and indices a_0..a_{n-1}
such that each image x " Icc(t_i, t_{i+1}) is contained in some U (a_i).
-/

variable {X : Type _} [TopologicalSpace X] {Œ± : Type _}

lemma path_subcover_segments (U : Œ± ‚Üí Set X)
  (hcover : (‚ãÉ a, U a) = (univ : Set X))
  (hopen : ‚àÄ a, IsOpen (U a))
  {x : ‚Ñù ‚Üí X} (hcont : ContinuousOn x (Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1)) :
  ‚àÉ (n : ‚Ñï) (t : Fin (n+1) ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (a : Fin n ‚Üí Œ±),
    StrictMono t ‚àß t 0 = 0 ‚àß t (Fin.last n) = 1 ‚àß
    ‚àÄ i : Fin n, x '' (Icc (t (Fin.castSucc i)) (t (Fin.succ (Fin.castSucc i)))) ‚äÜ U (a i) := by sorry

name: benmckay_top_fundamental-groups_17
nl_statement: Let $X$ be a topological space and let $x,y\colon[0,1]\to X$ be paths. Suppose there exists a continuous, strictly increasing map $\tau\colon[0,1]\to[0,1]$ with $\tau(0)=0$, $\tau(1)=1$ and $y\circ\tau = x$ (so $y$ is a reparametrization of $x$). Prove that $x$ is homotopic to $y$ relative to $\{0,1\}$.
lean4_code:
import Mathlib

/-!
Lemma: Reparametrisation of a path gives a homotopic path relative to the endpoints.

We work with maps defined on the unit interval `I := Set.Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1`.  If
`x y : ‚Ñù ‚Üí X` are continuous on `I` and `œÑ : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù` is continuous, strictly
increasing on `I`, fixes the endpoints `0` and `1`, maps `I` into itself, and
satisfies `y (œÑ t) = x t` for all `t ‚àà I`, then there exists a continuous homotopy
`H : ‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù ‚Üí X` on `I √ó I` witnessing that `x` and `y` are homotopic relative to
`{0,1}`.  For brevity we state the existence of such an `H` and its boundary
conditions; the proof is omitted (:= by sorry).
-/

open Set

variable {X : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X]

lemma reparametrization_homotopic_relative_endpoints
  (x y : ‚Ñù ‚Üí X)
  (hx : ContinuousOn x (Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1))
  (hy : ContinuousOn y (Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1))
  (œÑ : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
  (hœÑ_cont : Continuous œÑ)
  (hœÑ_maps : MapsTo œÑ (Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1) (Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1))
  (hœÑ_strict : StrictMonoOn œÑ (Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1))
  (hœÑ0 : œÑ 0 = 0)
  (hœÑ1 : œÑ 1 = 1)
  (hxy : ‚àÄ t ‚àà Icc (0 : ‚Ñù) 1, y (œÑ t) = x t) :
